document.text: with friends and doing some spring shopping. Mr. E. W. Gilliam, of Lynch burg, was a visitor here Sun day. Mrs. J. H. McCue returned from Bluefield, W. Va., on last Friday from a weeks visit to Mrs. O. 0. Jenkins, who has been quite ill for the past two weeks. Mr. J. W. Davis returned last week from Staunton, having spent several days with his son Prof. J. Talmage Davis, of the 8taunton Military Institute. Mrs. James Glenn, of Olive Branch, was called to the home of her father, Mr. Ben Rosser, who was reported as being quite siok on last Friday, and the many friends of Mr. Rosser are made more sad to learn of the serious accident to one of his sons,Mr. Bob Rosser, of Lynchburg, who, while rid ing a motorcycle, collided with an automobile, causing the loss of one leg, one broken arm and a severe cut on the head. Our citizens in this part of the county, on both north and south side of Appomattox river, are worked up to a point that our officials can not bring up the same old chestnut that is always politely handed to the farmer You havnot ask ed for anything, so why do you kick? And from what I have seen and heard, the citizens of this part of Clover Hill Dis trict will not be satisfied with nothing less than a good bridge across Appomattox riv er near the poi-t known as the John Marshall ford, and a com  mittee of 15 of the old straight liners has been appointed to meet with the Board of Super visors at their regular meeting and investigate further into the matter. And since your correspondent has somewhat the resemblance of Foxy Grandpa, I will say nothing as to finances. Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Harden, Miss Alice Harden and Mr Turner, of Fife, are on a visit to Mrs. Hardens mother, Mrs J. W. Harwood. Rev. Mr. Sam Harwood and wife and Mrs. Laokford, of! Jarretts, are also on a visit to Mrs. Harwood. Miss Ruth Harwood, of Hope well, spent the week-end with home people. Mr. J. R. Fore was down to Gamp Lee on Thursday.

The common school was his hobby, if it may be said he had one He would not minimize the importance of the universities and high schools, bu he declared a hoy. with a common school education, who attend chuich and public speaking and read his county paper, was an edu cated mau at 35 years or a fool The Senator did not. avree with the program iu advocating a nine months session. A five mouths es sion is too shoit, but the 1 cui au thorities know better about the taxes. If school trustees dont d their duty make it so hot for them that they will be turned out. He urged the people to spend their money in educating the children At the conclusion of the Sena tors speech Hon. J. W. Harwood arose and said he was compelled to take issue with the Senator. The audience showed its uneasiness, but Mr. Harwood soon relieved hi saying that the Senator had made a splendid address that showed prep oration and thought. Rev. W. E. Warren then intro duced Supt. J. D. Eggleston, of Prince Edward couuty, who made a fine impression, and was declared to be the best speaker of the day. He said that whenever the school offi cers show to the people that every cent paid into the treasury is paid out properly, there is no trouble in getting sufficient funds to run the schools. document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: Hixburg Items. The many frieuds of the Hon. H. D. Flood about here are of course in high feather, as he coutinues to step upward on the ladder of fame, and as he has so ably filled the many positions of trust to which he has been called, wemey with confi dence expect him to bring success to party, honor to himself and his native county and good to all of the people of the Tenth Congressional District. We all love Harry Tucker, and an able true man he is but unfortunately for him, he appears this time to he the representative of the crown of thorns and cross of gold policy, so let us all hurrah tor Bryan and Sewall, Hall Flood and Free Silver Not only hurrah but use all honor able means to bring about their elec tion. Crops are fairly good in this section, but just now are much in need of a copious shower. Society people here have been having a good time indeed for some weeks back. In addition to our own bevy of beauties, we have been vis ited by Misses Mary and Eva Morton and Sallie Rice, of Pamplin, Misses Annie McCraw, Virginia, Lizzie and Lelia Gilliam, of Buckingham, Miss Bessie Perrow, of Lynchburg, and last by no means least by Miss Sallie Burke and Cousin Mary Taylor cf your own town. This influx of beauty and facination has so be wildered our young men, that they have been earnestly striving to find out just which was which and  where they are at, anyway correspondent is not a prophet, so we will have to await results. When the leaves fall again. Mrs. Annie Earle, nee Hix, of Texas, is again iu the Old State, with her children, visiting her father.  Mrs. Sherman, of Lynchbnrg, is visiting this week at the hospitable home of W. L. Ford, Esq. Miss Carrie Hix died here at the home of her brother W. D. Hix,Esq., on last Wednesday of heai t disease and was buried on Thursday morn ing in the church-yard, by a host of sorrowing friends and relatives. Bnrial service was conducted ty Rev, J. C. Leps assisted by Mr. J. W. Harwood. P e t e r R u f u s .

document.text: At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce here Tuesday reso lutions were passed urging the Highway.Commission to push the construction of Route 10, the most important highway of the state, to completion and make hard surface between Petersburg and Appomattox. The following committee was appointed to meet with citizens all along the road from Appomattox to Petersburg, at Burkeville, todry, to further urge the commission to complete the road S. L. Furgeson, Arthur Irby, A. R. Harwood, J. W, Flood and A. H, Clement The condition of the road is very bad, so bad that the Farmville buss has been discontinued and auto travel between here and Farm ville is dangerous in wet weather.

document.text: Tobacco M en in C onference The tobacco interests of Ap pomattox will be ably repre sented at South Boston to-day, where the question of market ing facilities at Appomattox will be considered. A ppomat- tox is to make every provision for the proper handling of all grades of tobacco, which will be a great convenience to the members x of Co - operative marketing in this section of Virginia. Among those attending from this county we note W. 0 Moss, R. L. Burke, H C. Bab cock, A. R. Harwood, J. E. Sears, W. U. Byrne, Jno. C. Moore, Jr., and M. C. Smith. Mr. S. V. Panlett, of Pamplin, was in town yesterday and said that Pamplin would be represented at the meeting. Our director, W. C. Wingfield, is scheduled to be here before a meeting on the 15th instant to enlighten the members of the association. Beginning the conference with the warehousemen of four states at South Boston, Va , on Wednesday, April 5th, continu ing conferences at Greensboro and Raleigh, N. C , on April 6th and 7tb, and ending the meetings at Florence, S. O., on Saturday, April 8tb, Warehouse Manager T. C. Watkins and the committee on warehouses will report to a full meeting of the directors of the association in Raleigh on Tuesday, April lltb. The recent selection of Oliver J. Sands, of Richmond, presi dent of the American National Bank of that city, as manager of the Marketing Association, and the choice of Frank D. Williams, the skillful leader of the sun cured pool of Virginia, and well-known leaf dealer, as manager cf the Dark Leaf De partment will further insure the success of the association in three states. Growers in both the Carolina and Virginia are urged to sup port the many meetings being held this week and to win new signers to the contract.

document.text: Joseph 0- OBrien, 49 years of age, died Monday morning in a Lynchburg hospital, where he had been ill for three weeks. Mr. OBrien was a native of Lynchburg, being a son of the late William A. OBrien. He is survived by his widow, two song, Otway and Randolph, of Lynch burg four daughters, Mrs. Ellis Brame, of Chase City Misses Elizabeth, Virginia and Adeline OBrien, of Appomattox three brothers, William OBrien Jr., of Kyle, W. Va. and E. H. and Gray L. OBrien of Lynchburg and three sisters, Mrs. C. B Johnson, Lynchburg Mrs. C. P. Hardaway, Bluefield, W. Va. and Miss Marion OBrien, of Takoma, Md. Deceased was a steward in Appomattox Memorial church and lay evangelist, and at the time of his death had charge of the fresh meat department of H. M. Burge Co., here. He was perhaps the best judge of live stock in the county and was  frequently , called uppn by our farmers in judging and administ ing to ill stock. He was popular and had many warm friends who sorrow with his family in his death. Funeral services were conduct ed from the Methodist church here by Rev. George Reamy, his pastor, assisted by Revs. Red ding, Clark and Caudil before a large crowd of friends of the ramily and burrial was made in the Caldwell cemetery at East I Ridge Farm. Honorary pall-bearers Drs. D. A. Christian, D. N. Twyman, W. G. Ould, L. E. Smith, H. C, Babcock, J. H, Cheatham, L. Orawley, C. S. McDearmon, R. Irby, J. D. Morris, W. R. Rey lolds, George R. document.text: Miss Maryland Virginia Smith,37, secretary to the superin,endent at the State Penitentiary, was killed instantly shortly after 7 oclock Sunday night when siie was s ruck by an automobile as she walked along route 460 about half a mile east of Bedford. Driver of the automobile, Russell W. Orange, 19, of Thaxton, was booked on a charge of manslaughter and released on 2,000 bond at Bedford county jail. Miss Smith was walking along the highway wiih . er sister, Mrs. R. W. Jamerson, of Webber City, just outside Bed ford, when she was hit. She was spending the week-end with her sis- .. According to deputy sheriff Dillard W. Shields, the two women were walking eastward along the side- of the highway when the Orange machine, traveling in the same direction, passed another ma chine, operated by Roy Bowyer, of Bocock Crossing, and struck Miss Smith as the two cars were running adjacent along the road. Besides Mrs. Jamerson, Miss mAh is survived by her father, M. C. Smith of Appomattox an other sister, Mrs. O. L. Sihefflerof Appomattox and six brothers, C. W. Smith, clerk of Appomattox Circuit Court LeRoy Smith, Appo- mat cx postmaster and S. Guy Smith also of Appomattox E. C. Smith of Clintwood E. G. Smith of Lu- ay, and W. I. Smith of Dufham, N. C. Funeral services were held at 3 M,, January 23 from Memorial Methodist Church here, conducted by Rev. W. R. Reed, and Rev. H. Frederick Jones. Interment was in ..ber y Cemetery. C., ever thoughtful of the Confede rate veterans, served a bountiful Thanksgiving dinner after they lad listened to a most excellent ser mon by Rev. R. W, Norris, of Pam plin, to the Gamp and the Chapter in Liberty Baptist Ohnroh. The adies and friends of the Chapter donated the.edibles and never were people more liberal. document.text: Frank Dresser Jr. and Edward Scott Cates spent several days this week in the home of Dr and Mrs. Foscue, of Lawrence ville. Miss Henreitta Roberts, of Nor folk, arrived Wednesday in Appo mattox and she will re nine her place on the local school faculty next week. Mrs. R. F. B. Steele and child ren have returned to their home in Petersburg after visiting in tie Burke home several days. John .T. Hunter suffered the loss of a barn full of tobacco, by fire Sunday.  Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Marshall and family will move to South Bos ton September 8, where Mr. Mar shall is stationed with the Standard Oil Co. Mr. and Mrs. T. B. Collins will occupy their home. Mrs. H. P. Davis is spending this week in Richmond. Mr. and Mrs. A. R. Harwood, Miss Louise Gills and J. W. Caw- f.iorn attended the Appomattox As sociation Sunday School convention at the Spring Creek Baptist church on Sunday. This old church was founded in 1823. Misses Virginia Christian and Josephine Jenkins left Monday for Charlottesville, where they will teach this session. Mrs. Helene Welch is spending this week at Roanoke and Bedford. Mr. and Mrs. Ted Gills and daugh ter have returned to their home in Bluefield after a visit with relatives ,n Appomaattox. Mrs. Louella Morris is visiting .ier sister, Mrs. Ida Morris at her aome near Vera. Mr. and Mrs. Johq L. Harrison .ill leave Saturday for Tifton Ga., .here Hr. Harrison will be staton- id with the Soil Conservation Ser vice. Mr. Harrison has done valuable work with the Soil Conservation Service in Appomattox County for the past several years and has been active in civic affairs. Mrs. Harri son has been a popular employee at the Baifk of Appomattox. Mrs. G. F. Abbitt Jr. and daugh ter, Peyton, will return tonight from New York.

G. Trent, assisted by Rev. W. M. Thompson, and Rev. R. E. Redding. The active pallbearers were J. E. Dinwiddie, A. R Harwood, R. W. Burkey, C. T. Moses, H. W. McKinney, John E. Sears, H. M. There were many floral -de signs and a large number of flower bearers. The interment took place in the private lot in Liberty cemetery. Professional Cards l.USLIE F. document.text: Hixburg, Feb. 15.- Mrs. Colyer Parks is convalescing in the Lynch burg General Hospital. Mr. Witt Goins condition is a- bout the same. His visitors over the week-end were Mr. and Mrs. Harris of Lynchburg Mr. and Mrs. Jim Franklin and children, Dr. Twyman Williams, Rbert Walker Covington, and Robert Earl Pankey. Mr. and Mrs. H. E. Gilliam, of Lynchburg Mesdames H. M. Mar shall, J. K. Marshall and Alfred Harwood were recent guests in the home of Miss Maggie Hix. Mrs. W. M. Erwin was the lunch eon and dinner guest of Mesdames Alfred Harwood and J. K. Marshall on Tuesday. Major W. M. Erwin, Jr., xf Scott Air Force Base, has been notified that his tour there will be complet ed in May and that he will be re assigned, probably to a foreign country. Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Webb are the proud parents of a young son Micheál Edward. Mrs. D. T. Goin visited Mrs. Webb at the Southside Hospital on Monday evening. On Feb. 1, the house at Scot land, the ancestral home of the Joel Watkins family, of Appomat tox, burned. The plantation is now owned by Mr. E. H. Carson, but it had been in the Watkins family for at least 150 years. The home was built in 1824 by Joel Watkins, an architect, the grandfather of the Joel Watkins, Sr., of Farmville. It was an eight-room house, built of heart pine, with pine paneling chair- boards around the walls. On the plantation is a natural lake around which the foundations of Indian huts were unearthed not long aft- the War Between the States,

I .. , l , . i The regular annual meeting of shareholders of the Farmers National Bank was held Tuesday, Feb. 17,1976 at 230 p.m. for the purpose of electing officers and directors. Shown in the photo above are some of the members of the Board of Directors and some of the shareholders who attended the annual meeting. j Directors elected to serve until the 1977 annual meeting are W. M. Abbitt, E. W. Carson,-John C. Cole, J. B. Drinkard, Jr., T. DeWitt Evans, John S. Grinels, Alfred R. Harwood, Jr., William A. Hunter, J. E. Jamerson, W. E. Jamerson, J. A. Mathews, C. T. document.text: The Appomattox Ruritan Club met Tuesday night of this week. At a business session, Ned Han cock, vice-president, was named to succed A. R. Har.wood, Jr., as pres ident of the club. Mr. Harwood found it necessary to relinguish his office as president due to his ap- 1 roaching induction in the armed service of the United States. The club voted to retain Mr. Harwoods name on the membershFp roll as an honorary member. Edwin Fore, of Pamplin, was elevated to the vice-presidency. Rev. L. C. Shearer conducted a program, around the topic, What Appomattox Needs. Among those speaking on this topic were George F. Abbitt, Judge J. W. Flood, R. B. Hudgins and A. R. Harwood.

document.text: Over 600 members and visi tors attended home-coming services at Liberty Baptist church here last Sunday. At Sunday school services recognition of members of long service was given T- A. Walton and R. E. Caldwell, Sr., w ho lave each been members of the Sunday School for approxi mately 70 years, while L. E. Smith has served 42 years as a neacher. A packed church auditorium istened Sunday morning to an inspiring sermon by the pastor, the Rev.W.- M. Thompson, upon the text Upon Thi ! lock I Will Build My Church, following the morning service a bounteous dinner was served on the church grounds. During the afternoon a por trayal of scenes from the early listory of Liberty church was depicted and recognition ex pended-to friends arid former members. Among the visiting Ministers were E. F. Burnette, W. T- Henderson, R. E. Red ding, and Joe Lynch. Mr. and Mrs. A. S. Wdolridge were pre sented a bouquet as oldest liv ing members of the church and Garland Jackson Morris recog nized as youngest member Many messages of greetings were read. T h e Rev. E. J. Wright preached at the Sunday night service. The following people served on Home-Coming committees On invitations, T. A Walton, A. iT. Inge and Miss Louise Gills. On tables, W- M. Hancock, L. E. Smith, Joe LeGrand, J. D. Morris, Miss Grace Caldwell, Mesdames A. R. Harwood, L Crawley, Pitzer Gills, and J. D- Moses. On music, Mrs. L. E. Smith, Don Moses, W. W. Scott, and Miss Cornelia Gills.
